metadata.case_name: Jage Ram & Anr. v. Hans Raj Midha

facts.text: Theft of cash box containing Rs. 10667/87 from Head Post Office, Kamal on 1-4-68, where Prem Prakash Midha worked as Clerk Incharge in Savings Bank Section.
Prem Prakash Midha reported the loss immediately to Assistant Post Master after returning from meeting his wife.
Report of theft given over telephone on same day; FIR issued under Sec. 380 IPC by Police Station, City, Karnal.
Investigation handed over to CIA Karnal on orders of Superintendent of Police, Karnal on 24-4-68.
Allegation: Prem Prakash interrogated at home before case entrusted to CIA, nothing incriminating found.
Allegation: On 5-5-68 at 5 p.m., taken away by ASI Dyal Chand and foot constable as wanted by Inspector Jage Ram CIA.
Ravinder Mehta (brother-in-law) visited CIA Staff office on 5-5-68, found Prem Prakash in custody but not allowed to meet.
Father visited Police Station Model Town on 6-5-68, not allowed entry or to interview son, heard cries of torture.
Ravinder Mehta and father visited CIA on 7th, 8th, 9th May 1968, heard cries and wailing indicating torture by Jage Ram and Dyal Chand.
Habeas Corpus petition filed by Hans Raj Midha on 10-5-68 for production of son Prem Prakash, alleging illegal detention and torture.
HC Judge Jindra Lal on 10-5-68: Issued rule returnable 13-5-68, appointed Reader Sadhu Ram Gupta to search CIA office with petitioner; ordered production and medical exam by CMO Kamal.

Reader's report: Reached CIA at 8.30 p.m. on 10-5-68 with father and Narinder Singh; heard Prem Prakash's voice, found him on gunny carpet with swollen feet and head injuries; detained since 5-5-68, beaten daily with chanda; no papers or diary.
ASI Dyal Chand arrived on cycle at 9.25 p.m., identified, asked to stay but left; later returned with fabricated zimini dated 10-5-68.
Jage Ram arrived at 10.50 p.m., claimed legal arrest; showed FIR No. 88 dt. 1-4-68 u/s 380 IPC, zimini No. 25 dt. 10-5-68 (freshly written), remand application endorsed 10-5-68.
Detenu taken to Duty Magistrate at 11.35 p.m. without medical exam; Magistrate ordered judicial remand till 13-5-68 and medical exam.
CMO examined at 8.45 a.m. on 11-5-68, found injuries; admitted to hospital.

Respondents' affidavits: Prem Prakash not traced till 10-5-68; arrested at 12.30 p.m. on 10-5-68 after reporting; search memo, injury memo (old injuries noted); case diary written; remand papers prepared late due to election duty.
Dayal Chand's version: Left to inform Jage Ram upon High Court gentleman's request, hard of hearing, didn't hear call back.
Jage Ram's version: Informed by Dayal Chand of High Court gentleman brought by S.M. Mehta (brother-in-law?) as safarashi; prior safarashi letters from Magistrate Gurdial Singh Nurpuri.
On 13-5-68, before Khosla J.: Detenu examined, stated taken on 5-5-68, tortured daily by respondents; corroborated by medical report (6 injuries), reader's report.
HC order (Khosla J.): Found illegal confinement till 10-5-68, torture by respondents; affidavits false; remitted to judicial custody; suggested matter to higher authorities.

legal_issues.text: Whether remarks made by High Court against appellants (police officers) in habeas corpus order regarding illegal detention and torture of Prem Prakash Midha prior to 10-5-68 should be expunged.
Whether High Court remarks were justified, considering opportunity to parties, evidence on record, and necessity for decision.

petitioner_arguments.text: Accused arrested only on 10-5-68 at 12.30 p.m., not earlier; no illegal custody or torture; injuries old.
Remarks unjustified, no opportunity or enquiry; impede investigation and affect career; High Court procedure improper.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: State of U.P. v. Mohammad Naim

petitioner_arguments.text: Prior safarashi letters explain suspicion; petition filed after arrest.

court_reasoning.text: High Court justified in inquiring into illegal detention allegations to protect constitutional freedom; appellants had opportunity via affidavits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Duty to safeguard liberty without impeding lawful police functions.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence (detenu's statement, reader's report, medical report with 6 injuries, divergences in affidavits) supports finding of arrest before 10-5-68 and torture.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Divergences like Dayal Chand's hasty departure and false zimini indicate fabrication.

court_reasoning.text: Remarks justified per criteria in State of U.P. v. Mohammad Naim: parties before court, evidence on record, necessary for decision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Judicial pronouncements must be sober but based on record.

court_reasoning.text: Safarashi letters from judicial magistrate improper, undermine confidence; refer to High Court.

holdings.text: Remarks neither unwarranted, unnecessary nor irrelevant; no ground to expunge.
High Court procedure justified in urgent habeas corpus; criteria for remarks satisfied.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of U.P. v. Mohammad Naim
precedents_cited.relevance: Criteria for judging if remarks against authorities are disparaging: opportunity, evidence, necessity.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of theft for which investigation conducted.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Remand orders, production, search warrants implied in habeas corpus proceedings.

outcome.summary: Appeal against High Court order refusing to expunge remarks on police officers for illegal detention and torture dismissed; findings upheld based on evidence.

key_quotes.text: "Reading of the statement made by the detenu together with the allegations... point un-mistakenly to the contention... that detenu had been taken into custody... on 5th of May 1968... and was maltreated by the respondents."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: HC finding on illegal custody and torture.

key_quotes.text: "I have no hesitation in finding that the detenu had been taken into custody on some date before the 10th of May and tortured by the Respondents."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court

key_quotes.text: "There is no warrant for the submission that the Appellants were not given an opportunity to explain nor that no enquiry was made against them."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: SC upholds opportunity given via affidavits.
